• US equity index futures suggest downside pressure at open
  • Big US banks kick off earnings; heavy data calendar
  • STOXX 600 down ~1%
  • Dollar gains; gold, crude futures fall
  • US 10-Year Treasury yield ~1.10%

Jan 15 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of markets brought to you by Reuters reporters. You can share your thoughts with us at markets.research@thomsonreuters.com


TOO-FAR, TOO-FAST MARKET? (0920 EST/1420 GMT)

Since their March 2020 lows, U.S. stocks have had quite a run. The S&P 500 index .SPX has rallied around 70% on a closing basis, with little in the way of any significant setback.

As a result, on December 4, the SPX ended around 17.1% above its 200-day moving average (DMA), which was its greatest level of disparity vs this closely watched longer-term moving average since December 2009:



Relatively high disparity readings can suggest a market has advanced too-far, too-fast, and may be vulnerable to a reversal from an extended position.

That said, another approach to using disparity can be convergence/divergence. Since December 4, the SPX has managed to add another 2.5%, yet the disparity reading has deflated and ended Thursday at 15.3%.

Of note, although timing can be blunt, looking back to 2007, significant market highs were preceded by SPX/200-DMA disparity divergence.

In any event, here is a table of a number of major, and market leading, indexes with their latest 200-day disparity reading:

Clearly, many of these indexes are running hot on a relative basis compared with the long-term moving average. Meanwhile, divergence has been in place on the Nasdaq .IXIC, the S&P tech sector .SPLRCT, and NYSE FANG+TM index .NYFANG since early September.

(Terence Gabriel)
